title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: Factor analysis one widely used methods social behavioural sciences. single latent factor fits covariance among set observed indicators, researchers routinely form composite score use subsequent causal analyses. practice implicitly assumes structural interpretation latent factor model: latent variable , rather individual indicators, causally efficacious. measurement model fits well guarantee structural interpretation correct. indicators direct causal effects outcome, even though covariance structure perfectly consistent single latent factor. structural interpretation wrong, causal conclusions drawn composite scores may misleading. VanderWeele Vansteelandt (2022) showed structural interpretation imposes testable empirical constraints. structest package implements two GMM-based tests—T0T_0 T1T_1—can reject constraints, providing researchers principled way evaluate whether structural interpretation tenable.

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: Consider reflective latent factor model dd indicators: Xi=μi+λiη+εi,=1,…,d X_i = \mu_i + \lambda_i\,\eta + \varepsilon_i, \qquad = 1, \ldots, d η\eta latent variable, λi\lambda_i factor loadings (reliabilities), μi\mu_i intercepts, εi\varepsilon_i independent error terms. structural interpretation, latent variable η\eta causally relevant quantity. external variable ZZ affects η\eta (indicators η\eta), Theorem 1 VanderWeele Vansteelandt (2022), indicators ii, jj values zz, z*z^*: λi{E(Xj∣Z=z)−E(Xj∣Z=z*)}=λj{E(Xi∣Z=z)−E(Xi∣Z=z*)} \lambda_i \bigl\{E(X_j \mid Z=z) - E(X_j \mid Z=z^*)\bigr\} = \lambda_j \bigl\{E(X_i \mid Z=z) - E(X_i \mid Z=z^*)\bigr\} identity testable observed data. T0T_0 T1T_1 tests formalise overidentifying restrictions GMM framework.

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: T0T_0 test (Section 3.2 paper) models conditional expectations : E(Xi∣Z=zj)=γi+λiλ1βj E(X_i \mid Z = z_j) = \gamma_i + \frac{\lambda_i}{\lambda_1}\,\beta_j β1=0\beta_1 = 0 (reference level). gives d×pd \times p moment conditions d+p−1d + p - 1 free parameters, yielding (d−1)(p−1)(d-1)(p-1) degrees freedom. test requires estimated reliability coefficients λi\lambda_i, obtained pairwise covariances via quasi-Poisson GLM. use: d≥3d \geq 3 indicators p≥2p \geq 2 levels ZZ.

what: Example: data consistent with the structural model
title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: data generated structural model, test statistic small pp-value large—fail reject H0H_0.
code: set.seed(12345) n <- 5000 d <- 5  # Simulate under the structural model z <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5)                        # binary auxiliary variable eta <- 1 + 0.5 * z + rnorm(n)                 # latent factor affected by Z lambda <- c(1.0, 0.8, 0.6, 0.9, 0.7)         # factor loadings X <- matrix(NA, n, d) for (i in 1:d) {   X[, i] <- 2 + lambda[i] * eta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5) }  # T0 test (should NOT reject) result_t0 <- test_t0(X, z) print(result_t0) #>  #>   T0: Reliability-dependent test of structural interpretation (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022)  #>  #> data:   X and z  #> statistic = 6.074, df = 4, p-value = 0.1937 #> n = 5000, d = 5 indicators, p = 2 Z-levels

what: Example: data violating the structural model
title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: Now consider data ZZ affects indicator disproportionately, violates structural interpretation: test statistic large pp-value small, correctly rejecting structural interpretation. can inspect full output summary():
code: set.seed(12345) eta <- rnorm(n) X_bad <- cbind(   2 + 1.0 * eta + 0.5 * z + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   3 + 0.8 * eta + 2.0 * z + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   # disproportionate Z effect   1 + 0.6 * eta - 0.3 * z + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   2 + 0.9 * eta + 0.4 * z + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   1 + 0.7 * eta + 0.8 * z + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3) )  # T0 test (should reject) result_t0_bad <- test_t0(X_bad, z) print(result_t0_bad) #>  #>   T0: Reliability-dependent test of structural interpretation (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022)  #>  #> data:   X_bad and z  #> statistic = 2226, df = 4, p-value = < 2.2e-16 #> n = 5000, d = 5 indicators, p = 2 Z-levels summary(result_t0_bad) #>  #>   T0: Reliability-dependent test of structural interpretation (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022)  #>  #> data:   X_bad and z  #>  #> Test statistic:  2226  #> Degrees of freedom:  4  #> P-value:  < 2.2e-16  #>  #> Sample size:  5000  #> Indicators (d):  5  #> Z-levels (p):  2  #> Convergence code:  1  #>  #> Parameter estimates: #>   gamma (intercepts): #>     X1     X2     X3     X4     X5  #> 1.7006 2.7836 0.8274 1.7447 0.7968  #>   beta (Z effects): #>   z=0   z=1  #> 0.000 1.728  #>   lambda (reliabilities): #> [1] 1.0099 1.0213 0.4555 0.9002 0.8222

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: T1T_1 test (Section 3.3 paper) avoids estimating reliabilities entirely. structural model, conditional expectations satisfy (Equation 3 paper): E(Xi∣Z=zj)=γi+αiβj E(X_i \mid Z = z_j) = \gamma_i + \alpha_i\,\beta_j α1=1\alpha_1 = 1 identification β1=0\beta_1 = 0 reference level. means matrix mean differences Δij=E(Xi∣Z=zj)−E(Xi∣Z=z1) \Delta_{ij} = E(X_i \mid Z = z_j) - E(X_i \mid Z = z_1) rank ≤1\leq 1 structural model. T1T_1 test checks rank constraint using two-step efficient GMM procedure, d×pd \times p moment conditions, 2d+p−22d + p - 2 free parameters, (d−1)(p−2)(d-1)(p-2) degrees freedom. use: d≥3d \geq 3 indicators p≥3p \geq 3 levels ZZ. Preferred T0T_0 rely error-structure assumptions needed reliability estimation.

what: Example: data consistent with the structural model
title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: , test reject—consistent data generated structural model.
code: set.seed(12345) n <- 5000 d <- 4  # Simulate under the structural model with a 4-level Z z <- sample(0:3, n, replace = TRUE) eta <- 1 + 0.3 * (z == 1) + 0.7 * (z == 2) + 1.2 * (z == 3) + rnorm(n) lambda <- c(1.0, 0.8, 0.6, 0.9) X <- matrix(NA, n, d) for (i in 1:d) {   X[, i] <- 2 + lambda[i] * eta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5) }  # T1 test (should NOT reject) result_t1 <- test_t1(X, z) print(result_t1) #>  #>   T1: Reliability-independent test of structural interpretation (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022)  #>  #> data:   X and z  #> statistic = 3.016, df = 6, p-value = 0.8068 #> n = 5000, d = 4 indicators, p = 4 Z-levels

what: Example: data violating the structural model
title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: structural interpretation rejected, expected.
code: set.seed(12345) eta <- rnorm(n) X_bad <- cbind(   2 + 1.0 * eta + 0.5 * (z == 1) + 0.3 * (z == 2) + 0.4 * (z == 3)     + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   3 + 0.8 * eta + 2.0 * (z == 1) + 0.1 * (z == 2) + 3.0 * (z == 3)     + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   1 + 0.6 * eta - 0.3 * (z == 1) + 0.8 * (z == 2) - 0.5 * (z == 3)     + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   2 + 0.9 * eta + 0.4 * (z == 1) + 0.6 * (z == 2) + 0.3 * (z == 3)     + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3) )  # T1 test (should reject) result_t1_bad <- test_t1(X_bad, z) print(result_t1_bad) #>  #>   T1: Reliability-independent test of structural interpretation (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022)  #>  #> data:   X_bad and z  #> statistic = 1400, df = 6, p-value = < 2.2e-16 #> n = 5000, d = 4 indicators, p = 4 Z-levels summary(result_t1_bad) #>  #>   T1: Reliability-independent test of structural interpretation (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022)  #>  #> data:   X_bad and z  #>  #> Test statistic:  1400  #> Degrees of freedom:  6  #> P-value:  < 2.2e-16  #>  #> Sample size:  5000  #> Indicators (d):  4  #> Z-levels (p):  4  #> Convergence code:  2  #>  #> Parameter estimates: #>   gamma (intercepts): #>     X1     X2     X3     X4  #> 2.0872 3.0878 1.0656 2.1163  #>   alpha (centered loadings): #>      X1      X2      X3      X4  #>  1.0000  7.7155 -1.5389  0.6065  #>   beta (Z effects): #>     z=0     z=1     z=2     z=3  #>  0.0000  0.2378 -0.0676  0.3796

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: estimate_reliability() function estimates factor loadings λi\lambda_i pairwise covariances. model Xi=μi+λiη+εiX_i = \mu_i + \lambda_i\,\eta + \varepsilon_i, Cov(Xi,Xj)=λiλj\text{Cov}(X_i, X_j) = \lambda_i\,\lambda_j. Taking logs gives logCov(Xi,Xj)=logλi+logλj\log \text{Cov}(X_i, X_j) = \log\lambda_i + \log\lambda_j, linear model log-reliabilities. function fits quasi-Poisson GLM log link. function called internally test_t0(), can use directly need reliability estimates purposes.
code: set.seed(12345) n <- 5000 d <- 5 eta <- rnorm(n) lambda_true <- c(1.0, 0.8, 0.6, 0.9, 0.7) X <- matrix(NA, n, d) for (i in 1:d) {   X[, i] <- lambda_true[i] * eta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5) }  rel <- estimate_reliability(X)  # Compare estimated vs true data.frame(   true = lambda_true,   estimated = round(rel$lambda, 3) ) #>   true estimated #> 1  1.0     0.974 #> 2  0.8     0.808 #> 3  0.6     0.594 #> 4  0.9     0.898 #> 5  0.7     0.695

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: Guidance: T1T_1 generally preferred depend error-structure assumptions needed estimate reliabilities (e.g., independent, homoscedastic errors). T0T_0 necessary 2 levels ZZ available, since T1T_1 requires p≥3p \geq 3. tests applicable (d≥3d \geq 3, p≥3p \geq 3), running provides useful sensitivity check. Agreement strengthens conclusion; disagreement may signal misspecification error distribution (affects T0T_0 T1T_1).

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: VanderWeele, T. J. Vansteelandt, S. (2022). statistical test reject structural interpretation latent factor model. Journal Royal Statistical Society: Series B (Statistical Methodology), 84, 2032–2054. doi:10.1111/rssb.12555

what: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model
title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model
text: R package implementing statistical tests : VanderWeele, T. J. & Vansteelandt, S. (2022). statistical test reject structural interpretation latent factor model. Journal Royal Statistical Society: Series B (Statistical Methodology), 84, 2032–2054. doi:10.1111/rssb.12555

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model
text: Factor analysis routinely used assess whether single univariate latent variable explains covariance among set observed indicators. one-factor model fits adequately, researchers typically form composite score (e.g. mean items) treat measure underlying construct subsequent causal analyses. practice implicitly assumes structural interpretation latent factor model: latent variable, rather individual indicators, causally efficacious. However, basic measurement model fitting well imply structural interpretation correct. individual indicators separate causal effects outcomes, even though covariance structure consistent single latent factor (see Figures 2 3 paper). VanderWeele Vansteelandt (2022) show structural interpretation imposes testable empirical constraints. Specifically, structural latent factor model, association external variable Z indicator X_i, scaled reliability X_i, must across indicators (Theorem 1). package implements two GMM-based tests exploit constraints: T0: test depends estimated reliability coefficients (Section 3.2) T1: test independent reliability estimates (Section 3.3)

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model
Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model
text: T0 test uses estimated reliabilities construct moment conditions hold structural interpretation. requires least 3 indicators discrete auxiliary variable Z least 2 levels. null hypothesis structural model holds, test statistic follows chi-squared distribution (d - 1)(p - 1) degrees freedom.
code: library(structest)  set.seed(12345) n <- 5000 d <- 5  # Simulate data under the structural model z <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5)                         # binary auxiliary variable Y <- 1 + 0.5 * z + rnorm(n)                    # latent factor affected by Z lambda <- c(1.0, 0.8, 0.6, 0.9, 0.7)          # reliabilities X <- matrix(NA, n, d) for (i in 1:d) {   X[, i] <- 2 + lambda[i] * Y + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5) }  # Run T0 test (should NOT reject) test_t0(X, z) # Now simulate data where Z affects indicators differently (violating the structural model) set.seed(12345) Y <- rnorm(n) X_bad <- cbind(   2 + 1.0 * Y + 0.5 * z + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   3 + 0.8 * Y + 2.0 * z + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   # disproportionate Z effect   1 + 0.6 * Y - 0.3 * z + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   2 + 0.9 * Y + 0.4 * z + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   1 + 0.7 * Y + 0.8 * z + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3) )  # Run T0 test (should reject) test_t0(X_bad, z)

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model
text: T1 test avoids estimating reliabilities entirely parameterising conditional expectations E(X_i | Z = z_j) = gamma_i + alpha_i * beta_j, alpha_1 = 1 beta_1 = 0 identification (Equation 3 paper). structural model, matrix mean differences Delta_ij = E(X_i | Z = z_j) - E(X_i | Z = z_1) rank <= 1. T1 test checks rank constraint using two-step efficient GMM procedure. test requires least 3 indicators least 3 levels Z. null, test statistic follows chi-squared distribution (d - 1)(p - 2) degrees freedom.
code: set.seed(12345) n <- 5000 d <- 5  # Simulate data under the structural model (Z with 4 levels) z <- sample(0:3, n, replace = TRUE) Y <- 1 + 0.3 * (z == 1) + 0.7 * (z == 2) + 1.2 * (z == 3) + rnorm(n) lambda <- c(1.0, 0.8, 0.6, 0.9, 0.7) X <- matrix(NA, n, d) for (i in 1:d) {   X[, i] <- lambda[i] * Y + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5) }  # Run T1 test (should NOT reject) test_t1(X, z)

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model
text: reliability coefficients can also estimated directly. model X_i = lambda_i * Y + epsilon_i, Cov(X_i, X_j) = lambda_i * lambda_j. reliabilities obtained fitting quasi-Poisson GLM log link pairwise covariances.

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model
text: basic (reflective) latent factor model assumes: X_i = alpha_i + lambda_i * eta + epsilon_i, = 1, …, d eta latent variable, lambda_i factor loadings (reliabilities), epsilon_i independent error terms. structural interpretation assumes eta, rather individual X_i, causally efficacious.

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model
text: structural latent factor model holds Z independent (X_1, …, X_d) conditional eta, , j, values z, z*: lambda_i {E(X_j | Z = z) - E(X_j | Z = z)} = lambda_j {E(X_i | Z = z) - E(X_i | Z = z)} identity testable observed data. T0 T1 tests GMM-based tests overidentifying restrictions implied identity.

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model
text: Parameterises E(X_i | Z = z) = gamma_i + (lambda_i / lambda_1) * beta_z tests overidentifying restrictions using GMM criterion. variance estimating equations adjusted uncertainty estimated reliabilities (see paper, p. 2041). Degrees freedom: (d - 1)(p - 1) Requires: d >= 3 indicators, p >= 2 Z-levels

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model
text: Parameterises E(X_i | Z = z_j) = gamma_i + alpha_i * beta_j alpha_1 = 1 (identification) beta_1 = 0 (reference level). Tests whether mean-difference matrix Delta_ij = E(X_i | Z = z_j) - E(X_i | Z = z_1) rank <= 1, testable implication structural model (Equation 3 paper). Uses two-step efficient GMM procedure. Degrees freedom: (d - 1)(p - 2) Requires: d >= 3 indicators, p >= 3 Z-levels

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model
text: T1 test generally preferred depend error-structure assumptions needed estimate reliabilities (e.g. independent, homoscedastic errors). However, 2 levels Z available, T0 test can used.

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model
text: VanderWeele, T. J. & Vansteelandt, S. (2022). statistical test reject structural interpretation latent factor model. Journal Royal Statistical Society: Series B, 84, 2032–2054. doi:10.1111/rssb.12555

title: Estimate Reliability Coefficients (Section 3.1) — estimate_reliability
text: Estimates reliability coefficients (loadings) \(\lambda_i\) indicator univariate latent factor model, using pairwise covariances quasi-Poisson GLM log link.

title: Estimate Reliability Coefficients (Section 3.1) — estimate_reliability
Estimate Reliability Coefficients (Section 3.1) — estimate_reliability
text: X numeric matrix (n x d) indicator variables, d >= 3. na.rm logical; TRUE, rows NA removed.

title: Estimate Reliability Coefficients (Section 3.1) — estimate_reliability
text: list components: lambda numeric vector length d estimated reliabilities. glm_fit fitted glm object. V_k matrix (n x d) per-subject estimating function contributions reliability parameters (used internally test_t0).

title: Estimate Reliability Coefficients (Section 3.1) — estimate_reliability
text: structural model \(X_i = \alpha_i + \lambda_i Y + \varepsilon_i\), \(\mathrm{Cov}(X_i, X_j) = \lambda_i \lambda_j\). log pairwise covariance modelled linear combination \(\log(\lambda_i)\), yielding quasi-Poisson GLM.

what: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
title: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
text: Tests whether structural interpretation univariate latent factor model can rejected, using GMM test accounts uncertainty estimated reliability coefficients.

title: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
code: test_t0(X, z, na.rm = TRUE, verbose = FALSE)

title: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
text: X numeric matrix (n x d) indicator variables, d >= 3. z numeric vector length n encoding auxiliary variable. Must least 2 distinct levels. na.rm logical; TRUE, rows NA removed. verbose logical; TRUE, print progress information.

title: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
text: object class c("structest_t0", "structest", "htest") containing: statistic T0 test statistic. parameter degrees freedom, \((d-1)(p-1)\). p.value p-value chi-squared distribution. method description test. data.name name data objects. estimates list gamma (intercepts), beta (Z effects), lambda (reliabilities). n_obs number observations used. d number indicators. p number Z-levels. convergence convergence code nlm. optim_details full output nlm.

title: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
text: structural model, \(E[X_i | Z = z_j] = \gamma_i + (\lambda_i / \lambda_1) \beta_j\). gives \(d \times p\) moment conditions \(d + p - 1\) free parameters (\(\gamma_1, \ldots, \gamma_d\) \(\beta_2, \ldots, \beta_p\) \(\beta_1 = 0\)), yielding \((d-1)(p-1)\) degrees freedom. variance GMM estimating equations adjusted uncertainty reliability estimates \(\lambda_i\).

title: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
text: VanderWeele, T. J. Vansteelandt, S. (2022). statistical test reject structural interpretation latent factor model. Journal Royal Statistical Society Series B, 84, 2032–2054.

what: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
title: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
text: Tests whether structural interpretation univariate latent factor model can rejected, without requiring estimation reliability coefficients. Uses centered indicators two-step efficient GMM procedure.

title: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
code: test_t1(X, z, na.rm = TRUE, max_iter = 1000L, tol = 1e-25, verbose = FALSE)

title: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
text: X numeric matrix (n x d) indicator variables, d >= 3. z numeric vector length n encoding auxiliary variable. Must least 3 distinct levels. na.rm logical; TRUE, rows NA removed. max_iter integer; maximum iterations alternating LS procedure. tol numeric; convergence tolerance alternating LS procedure. verbose logical; TRUE, print progress information.

title: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
text: object class c("structest_t1", "structest", "htest") containing: statistic T1 test statistic. parameter degrees freedom, \((d-1)(p-2)\). p.value p-value chi-squared distribution. method description test. data.name name data objects. estimates list alpha beta. n_obs number observations used. d number indicators. p number Z-levels. convergence convergence code nlm. optim_details full output nlm.

title: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
text: indicators centered row mean: \(X^c_{ik} = X_{ik} - \bar{X}_{\cdot}\), eliminates latent factor \(Y\). structural interpretation, \(E[X^c_i | Z = z_j] = \alpha_i \beta_j\) \(\alpha_i\) \(\beta_j\) identifiable nuisance parameters. test \((d-1)(p-2)\) degrees freedom. full model (Equation 3 paper) \(d \times p\) moment conditions \(2d + p - 2\) free parameters (\(d\) intercepts, \(d\) alphas, \(p-1\) betas, minus 1 alpha-beta scale indeterminacy), giving \(dp - (2d+p-2) = (d-1)(p-2)\) degrees freedom. procedure uses two-step efficient GMM: first fixed weight matrix initial estimates, efficient weight matrix.

title: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
text: VanderWeele, T. J. Vansteelandt, S. (2022). statistical test reject structural interpretation latent factor model. Journal Royal Statistical Society Series B, 84, 2032–2054.
